title: My Lab Journal
text: This is a template example for lab journaling. Students in the data science courses at the Institute of Entrepreneurship will use this template to learn R for business analytics. Students can replace this text as they wish.

title: My Lab Journal
text:
How to use

Accept the assignment and get your own github repo.
Blog/journal what you are doing in R, by editing the .qmd files.
See the links page for lots of helpful links on learning R.
Change everything to make it your own.
Make sure to render you website everytime before you want to upload changes

title: Class Notes
text:
IMPORTANT: You can delete everything in here and start fresh. You might want to start by not deleting anything above this line until you know what that stuff is doing.
This is an .qmd file. It is plain text with special features. Any time you write just like this, it will be compiled to normal text in the website. If you put a # in front of your text, it will create a top level-header.

title: Data Wrangling
text:
Note



You can delete everything in here and start fresh.

title: Tidyverse
text:
1 Load necessary libraries
library(dplyr) library(ggplot2) library(tidyr) library(stringr)


2 Read data from Excel files
bikes <- read_excel(“C:/Users/Shweta/Documents/GitHub/ss24-bdsb-shwetaambade/datascience/ds_data/ds_data/01_bike_sales/01_raw_data/bikes.xlsx”) bikeshops <- read_excel(“C:/Users/Shweta/Documents/GitHub/ss24-bdsb-shwetaambade/datascience/ds_data/ds_data/01_bike_sales/01_raw_data/bikeshops.xlsx”) orderlines <- read_excel(“C:/Users/Shweta/Documents/GitHub/ss24-bdsb-shwetaambade/datascience/ds_data/ds_data/01_bike_sales/01_raw_data/orderlines.xlsx”)


3 Merge dataframes
bike_orderlines_joined <- orderlines %>% left_join(bikes, by = c(“product.id” = “bike.id”)) %>% left_join(bikeshops, by = c(“customer.id” = “bikeshop.id”))


4 Extract state abbreviation from location
bike_orderlines_wrangled <- bike_orderlines_joined %>% separate(location, into = c(“city”, “state”), sep = “,”) %>% mutate(state = str_trim(state))


5 Calculating total price
bike_orderlines_wrangled <- bike_orderlines_wrangled %>% mutate(total_price = price * quantity)


6 Group by state and summarize sales
sales_by_state_tbl <- bike_orderlines_wrangled %>% group_by(state, city) %>% summarise(total_sales = sum(total_price)) %>% arrange(desc(total_sales)) # Arrange states by total sales, descending order


7 Visualize sales by state
sales_by_state_tbl %>% ggplot(aes(x = reorder(state, -total_sales), y = total_sales)) + geom_bar(stat = “identity”, fill = “#2DC6D6”) + labs( title = “Revenue by State”, x = “State”, y = “Revenue” ) + theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1)) # Rotate x-axis labels

title: Data Acquisition
text:
#API Challenge #load packages library
library(RSQLite) library(httr) library(jsonlite)

1 API key for OpenWeatherMap
api_key <- “1b974d3ef182f3948d75d15456fbbd20”


2 City for which you want to fetch weather data
city <- URLencode(“Berlin”)


3 API endpoint
url <- paste0(“https://api.openweathermap.org/data/2.5/weather?q=”, city, “&appid=”, api_key)


4 Make GET request to API
response <- GET(url)


5 Check if request was successful
if (http_type(response) == “application/json”) { # Parse JSON response weather_data <- fromJSON(content(response, “text”))
# Extract relevant information temperature <- weather_data\(main\)temp - 273.15 # Convert temperature from Kelvin to Celsius humidity <- weather_data\(main\)humidity
# Create dataframe to store weather information weather_df <- data.frame( “City” = city, “Temperature (°C)” = temperature, “Humidity (%)” = humidity, “Description” = weather_description )
# Print weather dataframe print(weather_df)
# If you want to save the dataframe to a table in a database, you can use RSQLite or any other database package
} else { cat(“Failed to fetch weather data.”) }
#Web Scraping

title: Data Visualization
text:

title: Links
text:
R is a free open-source programming language that can be used for statistical analysis, data-simulation, graphing, and lots of other stuff. Another free program is R-studio, that provides a nice graphic interface for R. Download R first, then download R-studio. Both can run on PCs, Macs or Linux. Students will be learning R in the stats labs using the lab manual .




Google is great, Google your problem
Stackoverflow is great, google will often take you there because someone has already asked your question, and someone else has answered, usually many people have answered your question many ways.
